1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Kingdom of Tonga for the Integrated Urban Development Sector Project. The report also 
describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Urban  Planning  and  Management  System,

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

Urbanization  is  only  a  relatively  recent  phenomenon  in  Tonga,  but  the  problems 
2. 
associated  with  unplanned  and  uncontrolled  development  are  already  being  experienced. 
Nuku'alofa, located on the island of Tongatapu, is the national capital and has a population of 
34,058.1 The population of Nuku'alofa represents 34% of the national population and about 75% 
of the national urban population. The annual growth rate in the Nuku’alofa urban area from 1996 
to  2006  was  0.85%.  Migration  to  Nuku’alofa  from  Tonga's  outer  islands  is  significant. 
Approximately 22% of households migrated to Nuku’alofa from other areas within Tonga during 
the  last  10  years,  half  of  whom  migrated  during  the  last  2  years.2  The  impact  of  rural–urban 
migration  on  Nuku'alofa's  population  has  been  reduced  by  overseas  migration,  with  30%  of 
households in Nuku'alofa reporting that household members had emigrated in the last 5 years. 

3. 
Under  the  Tongan  Constitution,  every  male  citizen  is  entitled  to  two  plots  of  land,  one 
rural  and  one  urban.  As  a  result  of  growing  demands  for  this  entitlement,  the  Government  is 
increasingly under pressure to allocate urban plots. It has resorted to allocating land within two 
low-lying areas of Nuku’alofa, namely the Popua district to the east of the urban area and the 
Sopu district to the west, both of which are areas of swampland that are continually flooded. 

4. 
The buildup of traffic in and around Nuku’alofa in recent years has meant that the main 
approach roads to the urban area, and roads in the town center, are experiencing congestion.3 
This  is  especially  severe  around  the  public  market  and  also  in  other  areas  at  peak  office  and 
school arrival and departure hours. Traffic congestion in the town center is exacerbated by the 
fact  that  vehicular  access  to  the  wharves  and  industrial  sites  to  the  east  of  the  primary  urban 
area  is  restricted  and  has  to  pass  either  through  or  close  to  central  commercial  areas.  In 
addition,  the  lack  of  adequate  traffic  management  in  strategic  locations  along  the  main  road 
network, and especially in terms of off-street parking, also contributes to traffic congestion.  

5. 
The lack of adequate sidewalks alongside many of the busiest roads results in significant 
conflict between pedestrians and vehicular traffic. The situation is particularly acute during rains, 
when roadside flooding forces pedestrians onto the main roadways. 

6. 
The  standard  of  road  maintenance  and  repair  is  low  and  usually  involves  repeated 
patching of damaged sections. Where roads are resurfaced, a new layer of chip seal is laid on 
top  of  the  existing  surfaces  without  repair  to  the  base  course  in  soft  areas,  resulting  in  rapid

7. 
The topography of Tongatapu is flat and low-lying. The highest elevation on Tongatapu 
is  70  meters  above  mean  sea  level.  Most  of  the  urban  area  of  Nuku'alofa  is  only  1–2  meters 
above that level and is subject to periodic flooding during heavy rain. Most floodwater eventually 
infiltrates into the limestone substrata, but there are extensive low-lying areas within the urban 
area that are frequently flooded and provide ideal conditions for mosquitoes and transmission of 
waterborne diseases. 

The existing drainage systems in the central areas of Nuku’alofa do not function well due 
8. 
to siltation and other forms of blockage, coupled with a general lack of repair and maintenance. 
Nuku'alofa has a number of open drainage channels with limited culvert interconnections. These 
channels frequently either have no outlets or their outlets are substantially blocked, resulting in 
stagnant  water  lying  for  days  until  it  eventually  infiltrates  or  evaporates.  Some  areas  of 
Nuku'alofa have very limited drainage systems and so stormwater collects at low points, where 
it infiltrates into the ground only after prolonged periods. 

Development  of  residential  subdivisions  in  low-lying  swampy  areas  such  as  Sopu  and 
9. 
Popua  is  constrained  by  the  presence  of  large  bodies  of  undrained  surface  water,  requiring 
substantial  filling  of  allotments  and  roads.  The  piecemeal  filling  of  roads  and  allotments  has 
altered the natural drainage patterns. The blockage of natural flow paths has created additional 
swamps and open water bodies. These result in flood damage to property, perpetually standing 
water, and a loss of access to unfilled allotments. 

10.  Most  households  in  Nuku'alofa  rely  on  individual  septic  tank  systems  for  wastewater 
disposal.  Many  septic  tanks  are  undersized  and  improperly  constructed  and  may  be  polluting 
the  groundwater  resources.  Contaminated  groundwater  discharging  to  the  coastal  fringe  and 
lagoon  areas  are  thought  to  be  the  cause  of  excessive  algal  growth,  and  there  are  concerns 
about impacts on the aquatic ecosystems. Monitoring of the groundwater quality is limited and 
does  not  allow  detailed  evaluation  of  groundwater  conditions.  Nuku'alofa's  water  supply  is 
sourced  from  Tongatapu's  aquifers.  Detailed  groundwater  and  hydrogeologic  analysis  is 
required  to  assess  the  impact  of  wastewater  disposal  methods  on  groundwater  quality.  The 
Project’s design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 

11. 
A  number  of  government  agencies  are  responsible  for  land  transportation  and  traffic 
management  in  Tonga.  The  MOW  is  responsible  for  planning  and  design  standards,  road 
construction, and maintenance. The Ministry of Police is responsible for vehicle licensing, traffic 
signals,  traffic  management,  and  traffic  enforcement.  The  Department  of  Environment/Ministry 
of Health is responsible for street cleaning and public health. The Ministry of Labor, Commerce 
and  Industries  is  responsible  for  bus  and  taxi  rates  and  operations.  Limited  interagency  and 
interdepartmental  coordination  has  resulted  in  inadequate  allowance  for  the  provision  of 
infrastructure  and  such  public  utilities  as  drainage,  water,  and  electricity  supply  lines  in  many 
road rights-of-way. 

 Civil  unrest  on  16  November  2006  caused  the  destruction  of  or  serious  damage  to 
12. 
approximately  25%  of  the  buildings  within  the  Nuku'alofa  central  business  area  (CBA).  In 
addition to the high reconstruction cost, the Tongan economy has suffered a decline in business 
activity and a substantial reduction in tourist arrivals. The Government has obtained a loan from 
the People's Republic of China for T$118 million ($62 million) for reconstructing the CBA. The 
reconstruction  activities  will  focus  on  replacing  the  buildings  destroyed  in  November  2006. 
Additional infrastructure works, beyond the scope of the reconstruction project, will be required 
within the CBA, although the nature and extent of the required works is yet to be fully assessed. 
An analysis of the urban sector in Tonga is in Appendix 2. 

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

Land Allocations. All land in the Kingdom of Tonga belongs to the Crown and is divided 
13. 
between the King’s land, the Royal Family’s hereditary estates, the nobles and chiefs' hereditary 
estates, and Government land. The nobles and chiefs' hereditary estates and Government land 
are  subdivided  into  allotments  for  the  rest  of  the  people  of  Tonga.  The  land  tenure  regulation 
stipulates  that  every  Tongan  male  over  the  age  of  16  is  entitled  to  a  rural  and  an  urban 
allotment. With growing urbanization, the Government has increasing difficulty in honoring this 
right,  and  it  has  been  forced  to  develop  marginal  land  on  the  periphery  of  Nuku'alofa.  As  a 
result,  many  people  in Nuku’alofa, and  particularly  the  most  vulnerable,  live  in  low-lying  flood-
prone areas unsuitable for housing and with poorly developed public infrastructure. To provide 
basic  public  infrastructure,  such  as  all-weather  roads  and  functional  drainage,  in  existing 
residential areas such as Sopu and Popua will significantly improve living conditions in terms of 
health  and  amenities  while  creating  opportunities  to  utilize  land  that  now  is  permanently 
waterlogged. 

14. 
Urbanization.  With  continued  rural-to-urban  migration,  development  pressure  in 
Nuku’alofa  is  increasing  and  existing  infrastructure  (particularly  roads  and  drainage)  does  not 
have  the  capacity  required  to  meet  growing  traffic  volumes  and  stormwater  runoff  associated 
with  urbanization.  Limited  recurrent  maintenance  of  roads  and  drains  has  exacerbated 
pressures on existing public infrastructure. Upgrading of existing infrastructure and development 
of  comprehensive  and  sustainable  maintenance  programs  to  meet  the  needs  of  the  growing 
population  are  required  immediately.  Land  for  urban  expansion  of  Nuku'alofa  is  limited  to  the 
peripheral  agricultural  and  ecologically  sensitive  areas.  Without  coordinated  and  systematic 
urban planning, urban population growth may increasingly push into more peripheral areas and 
result in underutilization of existing infrastructure and services and the costly extension of public 
utilities  and  services  into  new  and  more  remote  development  areas.  Recent  establishment  of 
the Planning and Urban Management Division (PUMD) provides the Government a mechanism 
to  plan  and  coordinate  urban  development.  Limited  qualified  and  experienced  staff  and 
resources  within  PUMD  constrain  the  Government  in  providing  effective  and  efficient  urban 
planning  and  management  services,  however,  and  there  is  an  urgent  need  to  build  capacity 
within PUMD.

restructuring has taken place in Tonga since a fiscal crisis occurred in 2005. In July 2006, the 
Government  significantly  downsized  the  administration.  Historically,  there  has  been  a  lack  of 
comprehensive  and  coordinated  planning.  Currently,  a  variety  of  departments  have  roles  in 
various aspects of planning and managing urban areas. The Ministry of Finance is responsible 
for  developing  the  Government’s  national  plan  and  providing  policy  advice  on  all  matters 
pertaining  to  social  and  economic  development.  The  Tonga  Water  Board  is  responsible  for 
providing  potable  water  to  the  urban  areas.  The  MOW  is  responsible  for  processing  building

resulted  in  the  development  of  residential  areas  on  unsuitable  land  on  Nuku'alofa's  periphery

urban  planning  is  required.  The  approach  must  be  flexible  to  meet  changing  investment

Tonga experienced annual growth in real gross domestic product (GDP) of about 2.4% 
over 2000–2005. As a result of Tonga’s dependence on global markets and weakening of key 

 economic  drivers,  and  including  a  reduction  in  remittances,  tourism,  and  agricultural  exports,

weakened  and  monetary  policy  was  tightened,  civil  unrest  erupted  in  November  2006.  This  is 
expected to lead to a further decline in economic performance.

Tonga’s public sector debt has remained stable at between 40% and 50% of GDP since 
the late 1980s and is estimated at 44% for FY2007. External debt makes up the bulk of public 
sector  debt.  With  most  of  the  external  debt  being  concessional,  the  net  present  value  of  the 
public sector debt is about 25% of GDP. In addition, contingent liabilities were estimated at 8% 
of  GDP  for  FY2005.  Tonga’s  debt  sustainability  remains  vulnerable  to  deteriorating  economic 
performance. Also at risk is the potential to use debt financing for productive investment that will 
support economic growth. The proposed ADF IX grant of $11.30 million to the Government will 
ease  the  macroeconomic  impact  of  the  large  financing  requirements  for  infrastructure

A. 

Economic Impacts 

52. 
Economic  analyses  were  undertaken  for  core  subprojects;  primary,  secondary,  and 
access roads; and the Sopu Drainage Channel. The analyses were conducted by comparing the 
discounted costs and benefits under “with” and “without” scenarios over 2008–2026 in constant 
2006 prices. The “without” case represents a continuation of the existing situation and the “with” 
case  represents  the  project  investment  scenarios.  The  economic  costs  accounted  for 
investments,  costs  of  project  implementation,  operations  and  maintenance,  environmental 
management  and  mitigation,  as  well  as  resettlement  and  land  acquisition.  Operations  and 
maintenance costs for the “with” investment cases were estimated at 0.625% of capital costs for 
the  three  primary  road  projects  and 1%  of  those  for  the  secondary  and  access  roads  and  the 
Sopu Drainage Channel. Taxes and duties were excluded from the analyses. 
 
The economic benefits for the road projects were evaluated in terms of fuel cost savings 
53. 
under  the  “with”  and  “without”  project  scenarios  and  account  for  differences  in  operation  and 
maintenance costs. A fuel price of T$1.80 per liter, equivalent to about $58 per barrel for Brent 
crude  oil,  was  applied  throughout  the  period  of  analysis.  The  estimated  annual  fuel  savings 
amount to 582,000 liters, equivalent to an average net present value of T$0.37 million, or 0.7% 
of fuel imports for the transport sector in FY2006. Most of the benefits from fuel cost savings are 
expected  to  accrue  to  users  and  passengers,  as  the  transportation  sector  is  deregulated  and 
competitive.  These  benefits  would  be  expected  to  include  lower  prices  for  consumer  goods 
along  with  improved  access  to  markets  and  basic  social  services.  Improving  secondary  and 
access  roads  in  Popua  and  Sopu  are  expected  to  primarily  benefit  the  lower-income  and 
most-vulnerable  households  and  enable  them  to  benefit  from  the  upgrades  of  primary  roads.

that  are  frequently  flooded  and  often  impassable  (Sopu  and  Popua).  The  Project  will  reduce 
poverty  by  lessening  the  financial  burden  of  repairing  flood  damage  to  properties  and,  just  as 
importantly,  substantially  improving  the  access  to  and  habitability  of  low-income  residential 
areas. It will also lessen health care costs by reducing areas of standing water. The improved 
access road conditions will reduce vehicle operating and repair costs.

URBAN SECTOR ANALYSIS 

Urbanization  is  only  a  relatively  recent  phenomenon  in  Tonga,  but  the  problems 
1. 
associated with unplanned and uncontrolled development are already being experienced. There 
are  only  three  urban  areas  of  significant  size,  which  are  the  capital  Nuku'alofa  on  Tongatapu 
island,  Neiafu  in  the  Vava'u  island  group,  and  Pangai  in  the  Ha'apai  island  group.  At  the  last 
census in 1996, their populations were 31,290 (Nuku'alofa), 5,650 (Neiafu), and 2,966 (Pangai). 
At that time, the population of Nuku'alofa was approximately 32% of the national population and 
about 75% of the national urban population. 

2. 
As  there  have  been  no  intercensal  population  counts  since  1996,  official  estimates  of 
current  population  are  largely  conjectural.  Based  on  available  projections,  however,  the 
population of Nuku'alofa is considered to be approximately 34,500,1 which assumes an annual 
growth rate in the urban area of 0.9% between 1996 and 2006. This rate is below natural growth 
rates due to the high incidence of emigration from Nuku’alofa, but it may actually underestimate 
rural-to-urban  migration.  The  recent  Nuku’alofa  socioeconomic  survey  undertaken  through  the 
project  preparatory  technical  assistance  revealed  that  22%  of  households  migrated  into 
Nuku’alofa from other areas in the last 10 years, with 11.6% migrating within the last 2 years.  2
Conversely, the socioeconomic survey confirmed a high rate of overseas migration, with 30% of 
households reporting that household members had emigrated in the last 5 years.3 

3. 
All land in Tonga belongs to the Crown and is divided between the King’s land, the Royal 
Family’s  hereditary  estates,  the  nobles  and  chiefs’  hereditary  estates,  and  government  land. 
The  latter  two  estates  are  subdivided  into  allotments  for  the  rest  of  the  people  of  Tonga.  The 
land tenure regulation stipulates that every Tongan male over the age of 16 is entitled to a tax 
allotment  of  8.25  acres  for  farming,  and  a  town  allotment  of  up  to  1,618  square  meters  for 
residential purposes, all of which is hereditary through the eldest male (heir).  

4. 
Population growth has intensified the demand for land, and regulatory entitlements can 
no  longer  be  fulfilled.  During  the  5-year  period  to  2000,  a  10%  decline  in  town  allotment 
registration  for  Tongatapu  suggested  that  pressure  for  space  in  Tonga’s  main  commercial 
center is compounding the issue of land availability limitations. Leasing of land is as common as 
registering land, and leases have different terms depending on their purposes.  

5. 
Nuku'alofa’s  growth  is  constrained  by  both  its  geography  and  the  absence  of  land 
development procedures conducive to planned development. The urban area is bounded on the 
north  by  the  ocean,  to  the  east  and  west  by  wetlands,  and  to  the  southeast  and  south  by  the 
Fanga'uta  Lagoon.  Other  than  furthering  development  by  increasing  development  densities  in 
the  existing  urban  area,  the  only  direction  available  for  significant  growth  is  to  the  southwest. 
Land  to  the  southwest  is  primarily  utilized  for  agricultural  purposes,  however,  and  is  held  by 
individuals in the form of tax allotments. 

6.

significant  scale,  inhibiting  land  acquisition  for  commercial  and  industrial  investment. 4   As  a

7. 
The buildup of traffic in and around Nuku’alofa in recent years has meant that the main 
approach  roads  to  the  urban  area,  and  roads  in  the  town  center,  are  congested. 5   This  is 
especially  severe  around  the  public  market  and  also  in  other  areas  at  peak  office  and  school 
arrival and departure hours. Traffic congestion in the town center is exacerbated by the fact that 
vehicular  access  to  the  wharves  and  industrial  sites  to  the  east  of  the  primary  urban  area  is 
restricted, and has to pass either through or close to central commercial areas. In addition, the 
lack  of  adequate  traffic  management  in  strategic  locations  along  the  main  road  network, 
especially in terms of off-street parking, also contributes to traffic congestion.  

8. 
The lack of adequate sidewalks alongside many of the busiest roads results in significant 
conflict between pedestrians and vehicular traffic. The situation is particularly acute during rains, 
when roadside ponding forces pedestrians onto the main roadways. 

9. 
There is a generally low standard of road maintenance and repair. Poor sections of road 
surface are repeatedly patched. When resurfacing does take place, a new layer of chip seal is 
laid on top of the existing surfaces without repair to the base course in soft areas. In addition, 
due  to  the  absence  of  adequate  road  drainage  and  poor  maintenance  of  existing  drains, 
ponding is frequent along roadways or over the roadways themselves. In 1998, the Ministry of 
Works  (MOW)  prepared  a  comprehensive  nationwide  road  improvement  program,  and 
considerable  work  has  been  done  in  completing  the  primary  and  secondary  roads  throughout 
Nuku’alofa. However, many of the roads completed prior to the 1998 plan have now exceeded 
their  useful  design  lives  and  again  require  resurfacing.  Furthermore,  the  surface  of  most 
localized residential access roads remain gravel and are badly broken and potholed. 

10. 
Limited  interagency  and/or  interdepartmental  coordination  means  that  inadequate 
allowance is made in many road rights-of-way for the provision of infrastructure and such public 
utilities as drainage, water, and electricity supply lines.

17. 
In the wake of significant government restructuring and downsizing in 2006, the roles of 
agencies  involved  in  urban  planning  and  management  are  in  a  state  of  flux.  Broadly,  the 
planning  and  provision  of  urban  services  is  undertaken  by  MOW  (roads,  drainage,  and  major 
projects),  Tonga  Water  Board  (water  supply),  and  Ministry  of  Civil  Aviation,  Marine  and  Ports 
(airports and ports). The latter was to be renamed the Ministry of Transport in July 2007. It will 
assume planning responsibilities for roads, while construction and maintenance will remain with 
MOW.  A  new  Waste  Management  Authority  came  into  being  in  October  2006  and  will  be 
responsible  for  solid  waste  collection,  management,  and  disposal  under  the  guidance  of  its 
Board.  There  are  no  centralized  sewerage  systems  in  Tonga,  and  on-plot  sanitation  has 
previously  been  overseen  by  the  Ministry  of  Health.  It  is  understood  that  this  responsibility  is

CORE SUBPROJECT OUTLINES 

The  drainage  rehabilitation  and  maintenance  program  is  intended  to  address  the 
1.

subproject  consists  of  two  parts:  (i)  procurement  of  equipment,  and  (ii)  cleaning  and 
rehabilitation of the drainage systems. 
 
2. 
Equipment  to  be  procured  includes  (i)  a  jet-and-vacuum  truck  with  a  capacity  of 
approximately  4.9  m3  to  enable  the  Ministry  of  Works  (MOW)  to  clean  pipe  and  culvert 
stormwater  drainage  systems,  and  (ii)  street  sweeping  equipment  to  reduce  the  frequency  of 
stormwater  drain  cleaning.  As  the  stormwater  drainage  systems  are  small,  the  equipment 
required can be purchased from the smaller end of the range available in the market. 
 
3. 
Given  the  magnitude  of  the  stormwater  drainage  cleaning  operation,  required,  bids  for 
the contract will be sought internationally and the contract will include provisions for employment 
and  training  of  local  staff  to  ensure  that  future  cleaning  operations  can  be  performed  by  local 
personnel. The contract will also include replacement or repair of damaged system components. 
 
B. 

Sopu Drainage Channel 

4. 
A  2.1-kilometer  (km),  gabion-lined  drainage  channel  extending  from  Hofoa  Road  to 
Tukingapahu Road in the Sopu area will be constructed. Initially, liners of clay or concrete were 
considered.  Clay  was  subsequently  ruled  out  due  to  its  propensity  to  scour  during  a  large 
volume storm event. Concrete was rejected, especially due to its high costs and constructability 
problems that could be anticipated given the high groundwater elevations in this area. Gabions 
were  selected  as  a  relatively  inexpensive  way  to  prevent  scouring  of  the  channel  sides  and 
bottom.  Furthermore,  as  the  gabions  are  permeable,  they  will  allow  groundwater  to  pass 
through the channel liner rather than exert hydrostatic pressure on the underside of the channel 
lining. Once the channel has been excavated to the desired elevation, the gabion wire baskets 
and  mats  may  be  set  in  place  and  then  filled  with  stone.  Consequently,  the  dewatering 
requirements are greatly reduced. 
 
5. 
Levees will be installed to the outside of the top gabions along both sides of the channel 
to provide access to the channel for periodic maintenance. The elevation of the levees will be 
similar to existing filled lots in the area so that as allotment recipients develop the adjacent lots 
they can fill to elevations that will allow their lots to drain without blocking drainage from the lots 
further away. Five concrete box culverts will be constructed to provide road crossings, including 
an  outlet  structure  at  Hofoa  Road.  The  culverts  are  1.0–1.2  meters  (m)  high  due  to  the 
limitations induced by existing roads and developed lots. Consequently, most of the culverts are 
the two-barrel type to provide sufficient flow area to accommodate the design storm event.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Tonga 
 
Some  23%  of  Tongan  households  are  estimated  to  experience  periodic  difficulties  in  meeting  their  basic  needs. 
The  Tonga  hardship  and  poverty  assessment  (2004)  identified  causes  of  poverty  as  the  lack  of  income 
opportunities and limited access to basic social services. Tonga has made progress toward achieving many of the 
targets in the Millennium Development Goals and access to safe water is widespread. 
 
As  Tonga’s  economic  growth  prospects  improve,  so  will  pressure  on  urban  areas,  especially  Nuku’alofa.  It  is 
forecast  that  Nuku’alofa  will  have  to  accommodate  up  to  1,000  new  households  during  2007–2020.  The 
Constitution of Tonga provides for allocation of land to every adult male citizen in both the town (town allotments) 
and rural areas (tax allotments). With growing urbanization, it has become increasingly difficult for the Government 
to meet this obligation, and it often must provide marginal land. Growing demand for town allotments in urban areas 
has forced urban expansion onto wetlands. It is estimated that there are more than 1,000 households already living 
in the wetlands. Hundreds more such allotments have been made but not yet occupied. As a result, many people in 
Nuku’alofa live in low-lying areas unsuitable for housing. With decreasing availability of suitable land and a rapidly 
growing urban population, social services in Nuku’alofa are deteriorating and sanitation, drainage, roads, and waste 
disposal  need  attention.  Coupled  with  recurring  flooding  in  the  low-lying  areas,  health  and  social  indicators  are 
declining. Tonga’s limited land resources, combined with the growing urban population, are increasing pressure on 
Nuku’alofa’s  living  conditions.  The  Government  acknowledges  that  in  order  to  sustain  growth,  health,  education, 
water  and  sanitation,  physical  infrastructure,  and  the  environment  must  be  improved.  With  improved  urban 
services, the Project will give lower income groups access to higher quality land and reduce the threat of flooding.

What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
A  detailed  social  and  poverty  analysis  was  completed  under  TA4648-TON. 1   The  analysis  identified  that  a

Nuku’alofa,  the  country’s  national  capital  and  largest  urban  area.  The  Project,  which  will  be 
implemented  by  the  Ministry  of  Works  (MOW),  will  also  enhance  capacities  in  urban  planning,

3.   
The  Subproject  will  include  constructing  a  2.1-km  drainage  channel  through  a  mainly 
residential  area  comprising  both  developed  (reclaimed)  and  undeveloped  land  parcels.  As  the 
area is developed for housing and land is filled, undeveloped blocks are subject to ponding of 
trapped water. The Sopu Drainage Channel will connect the largest isolated open water areas 
to  the  watershed  outlet,  allowing  these  areas  to  periodically  flush  during  rain  storms,  thereby 
reducing the health hazards they  presently induce. It will also provide a drainage route during 
storms  to  counter  runoff’s  backing  up  into  existing  homes.  Further,  the  drainage  channel  will 
establish a legal drainage easement within which no further construction will take place. It has

made available at the Department of Environment and IUDSP offices in Nuku’alofa; 
and 
properly  keeping  all  environmental  documents,  including  the  environmental  due 
diligence  and  monitoring  reports  for  each  subproject,  as  part  of  the  Ministry  of 
Works records. 

 
H.  

Findings and Recommendations 

 

31. 
Based  on  discussions,  review  of  documents,  and  field  assessment  of  the  Project,  it  is 
concluded that by rehabilitating and improving the surrounding urban infrastructure the Project 
will  assist  in  maintaining  the  environmental  quality  of  the  Nuku’alofa  foreshore  areas  and  the 
Fanga’uta  Lagoon,  and  it  will  maintain  the  water  quality  of  the  groundwater  resources  of  the 
area. The Project has strong community support in Nuku’alofa. The Project complies with ADB’s 
environmental  safeguard  policies  and  no  irreversible  or  significant  cumulative  impacts  have 
been identified. Thus, a more detailed environmental impact assessment is not warranted and 
the  summary  IEE  will  be  the  final  environmental  assessment  for  the  Project.  By  adopting  the 
environmental  mitigation  and  monitoring  measures  outlined  in  the  environmental  management 
and monitoring plan, the Project will not cause environmental concerns.  

I.  

Conclusions 

32. 
The Project is classified as category B. The initial environmental screening process and 
analysis  of  potential  environmental  impacts  concluded  that  the  Project  will  not  result  in  any 
direct or indirect significant adverse environmental impacts and will not require further study. All 
impacts can be satisfactorily mitigated and an  EMP has been prepared that contains practical 
mitigation measures. A full environmental impact assessment is not warranted. 

An  environmental  assessment  review  framework  has  been  prepared  that  will  guide
